Several forms of participle in Hebrew.text: There are different forms of the participle for each of the seven binyanim. There are two pa'al participles, a nif'al participle, a piel participle, a pu'al participle, a hif'il participle, a huf'al participle, and a hispa'el participle.

Several forms of participle in Aramaic.text: There are two pe'al participles, a ispe'el participle, a pa'el participle, an ispa'al participle, and af'el participle, and an isaph'al participle.

There is no present tense verb conjugati.text: In English, one can say "the boy runs" (the present tense,) or "the boy is running" (the "gerund.") In Hebrew and Aramaic however, there is no tense corresponding to "the boy runs."

The participle functions as the present.text: Because there is no distinction between the present tense and the gerund, and the words הילד הולך could mean either the present tense ("the boy runs"), or the gerund ("the boy is running,") and we would have to know from context which was intended.

Noun.text: A participle can function as a noun, eg רץ צריך נעליים,
, "a person who is running needs shoes." Here, the word
"running," functions as a noun, "a person who is running."

Adjective.text: A participle can function as an adjective, eg שמעון קודש,
, "Shimeon is holy," or "Shimeon is being holy."

Constructions.text: The participle can be combined with other words to produce different constructions, such as the past participle.
